âš¡ Benchmarks

BLite performance benchmarks vs SQLite using BenchmarkDotNet on .NET 10.

ğŸ“Š Benchmark Environment
  • OS: Windows 11 (23H2)
  • CPU: Intel Core i7-13800H (14 cores @ 2.50GHz)
  • Runtime: .NET 10.0.2 (X64 RyuJIT)
  • Last Run: February 13, 2026

âš ï¸ Important Note on SQLite Memory

The "Allocated" metrics shown for SQLite only measure managed .NET allocations. SQLite's native C library allocates significant unmanaged memory that is not captured by BenchmarkDotNet.

In reality, SQLite's total memory footprint is much higher than reported. BLite's allocations are fully measured since it's 100% managed code.

Why BLite Is Faster

  • âœ… C-BSON Format - Field name compression (2-byte IDs vs strings)
  • âœ… Zero-Copy I/O - Direct Span<byte> operations
  • âœ… Memory Pooling - ArrayPool for buffer reuse
  • âœ… Stack Allocation - stackalloc for temp buffers
  • âœ… Source Generators - Compile-time serialization code

Test Workload

Benchmarks use a complex Person document with:

  • 10 employment history entries
  • Nested address object
  • Lists of tags (5 strings per entry)
  • ObjectId, DateTime, Decimal types
  • ~150 fields total per document

Running Benchmarks

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/EntglDb/BLite.git
cd BLite

# Run all benchmarks
dotnet run -c Release --project src/BLite.Benchmark

# Results will be in:
# BenchmarkDotNet.Artifacts/results/*.md
ğŸ“„ Full Report

For complete benchmark data including error margins, standard deviations, and GC metrics, see BENCHMARKS.md in the repository.
